title: Dad fined £100 for parking at one of UK's 'most confusing' car park near airport
text:

A dad is being charged £100 after visiting a car park dubbed one of the UK’s “most confusing” - and he is not the first.

The Starbucks car park near Stansted Airport has become notorious for people landing parking tickets, after they wrongly assume they can also go into McDonald's, just four metres away, next door.

The site has even been the subject of comedian Joe Lycett’s hit TV show Got Your Back, Essex Live reports.

Joe Lycett got wind of the situation and called it “easily the most ridiculous car park set up you’ve ever seen”.

Now resident Peter Duncan, has spoken out about falling foul of the rules when he parked in Starbucks but went into McDonald’s for a Chicken Select meal.

The 52-year-old dad was fined £60 in June 2018, but failure to pay means it has now risen to £100.

Holidaymakers and staff are coming unstuck because they are mistaking two separate car parks for having the same rules.

The land - although both run by MET parking services - has been split into two separate car parks.

Anyone who parks in Starbucks' Southgate Car Park and then walks the very short distance to McDonald’s gets picked up on CCTV, clocked by Automatic Number Plate Recognition cameras and fined.

Mr Duncan, who is a team leader of security at Stansted Airport, said he had not seen the signs and is still refusing to pay.

"It's an awful place. When you drive in it looks like a normal service area, like any other motorway services. There's the Esso garage, Starbucks and McDonalds," he said.

(Image: Essex live WS)

"It was at the end of a shift, I finished at lunchtime and had to go visit a friend so thought I'll get something to eat, so I went to McDonald’s.

"I had parked there previously and all of a sudden this fine comes out of the blue.

"You walk in and they just watch you. There's CCTV everywhere. It was like they were watching me leave."

Mr Duncan has since been back to the car park, curious to find out how many people get caught out.

In just thirty minutes, he claims he saw 10 cars park in Starbucks but walk over to McDonalds.

"I sat by the window watching," he said.

"This family bounced across to McDonalds with their kids, seemingly unaware. It's a nice treat for the kids that’s going to cost them £100."

He told the families that they may have been fined and warned them to park elsewhere next time.

He said: "It's beyond a joke.

(Image: Essex live WS)

"Something has got to be done about it, it’s not clearly signed."

After his first appeal, the letter from Met Parking Services said: “The car park you parked in is not McDonald’s car park, their car park is adjacent to their restaurant.

"The terms and conditions of use of the car park are clearly stated on signs prominently displayed in this area. These include that the car park is for the use of Southgate Park customers while they are on the premises only, that McDonald's is NOT on Southgate Park and that there is no free parking for McDonald's.

"You have acknowledged that you left your vehicle in this car park while you went to McDonald's therefore we believe the charge notice was issued correctly and we are upholding it."

Met Parking Services has been approached for comment.
description: The Starbucks car park near Stansted Airport has become notorious for people landing parking tickets, after they wrongly assume they can also go into McDonald's, just four metres away, next door
